conversation.content: [hesitantly] So, um, I know this meeting probably isn't what you were expecting, but I felt like I needed to, uh, talk to you face to face about what happened with the trading algorithm last month.
[bitter] Face to face? [laughs] That's rich, considering your algorithm didn't see my face when it liquidated thirty years of savings in fourteen seconds, did it?

[quietly] The model was supposed to have safeguards, I mean, we tested it thousands of times in simulation, and the risk parameters were, well, they should have prevented exactly this kind of cascade failure from happening.
[shaky voice] Should have? My wife has cancer, okay? That money wasn't just numbers on a screen, it was her treatment, our house, everything we'd built together since we were twenty-three years old.

[anxiously] I understand you're angry, and you have every right to be, it's just that, um, the feedback loop that caused the sell-off was something we'd never seen before in fifteen years of market data, like a perfect storm of conditions.
[sarcastically] Oh, a perfect storm.

[defensively] Look, I'm not trying to make excuses here, but the algorithm detected what it thought was insider trading patterns and, err, it overreacted trying to protect the broader portfolio, which obviously [sighs] backfired catastrophically in your case.

[angry] In my case? There were four hundred and seventeen other 'cases' according to the news, real people whose retirements you vaporized while probably eating lunch at your desk, not even aware it was happening.
[very quietly] Actually, I, uh, I was at my daughter's school play when the alerts started coming in, and by the time I got to my laptop, the damage was already done, completely irreversible.
[frustrated] Your daughter still has a parent who can afford her school, doesn't she? [exhales] Mine won't even remember her grandmother because we can't afford the experimental treatment anymore.
[empathetically] That's... God, I'm so sorry. I mean, I've been working with the legal team to find ways to expedite the compensation process, but I know that probably sounds hollow right now.
[cold] Hollow. [pause] Yeah.

[earnestly] The truth is, um, I haven't slept properly since this happened, because every time I close my eyes, I see the cascading sell orders, the numbers just falling and falling, and I know each one represents someone like you.
[tired] You know what I see when I close my eyes? My wife's face when I told her we'd lost everything, that look of, of complete betrayal, like I'd failed to protect the one thing that mattered.

[hesitantly] Would it, err, would it help if I testified on your behalf about the systemic failures? I mean, I could explain how the algorithm wasn't supposed to be capable of this, how the risk management protocols were essentially, well, fraudulent in their promises.
[suspicious] Why would you do that?
[firmly] Because I wrote that code, and I believed it was safe, but I was wrong, and people like you shouldn't have to pay for my hubris about controlling market complexity with mathematical models.
[quietly] The lawyers say it could take three years to see any settlement, assuming the company doesn't declare bankruptcy first to avoid payouts. [sighs] We don't have three years.

[urgently] Listen, I shouldn't be telling you this, but there's a whistleblower fund I can help you access immediately, it's not the full amount, but it could cover medical expenses while the main case proceeds, if you're willing to work with me on this.
[carefully] Work with you? [long pause] After everything, you're asking me to trust you with literally the last chance my wife has? That's... I don't even know what to say to that.
